The Church of Hagioi Apostoloi Solaki is situated on the southeastern side of the Ancient Agora. It is the second monument within the Agora which remained intact, after the temple of Hephaestus, the so-called Thisseion. It dates to the last quarter of the 10th century, probably around the year 1000 AD. it is the first significant church of the Middle Byzantine period in Athens, as well as the first church of the so-called 'Athenian' churches. It combines two architectural styles, namely the concentrical church with the cross-shaped inscribed church. The exterior walls are built with the envlosed bricklayer method with stone blocks on the lower part of the wall, whereas they are decorated with ceramic decorative elements and kufic letters. The name 'of Solakis' is probably due to the family name of the family of donors, or to the name of the area where the church was built in later times. \nThe Byzantine church is built on the foundations of a fountain (Nymphaeum) dating from the 2nd century A.D. \nInside the church is located an arcosolium, i.e. a monumental tomb for some well-known deceased person, whereas more graves have been traced in the central part of the main church as well as in the narthex.

The church of the Taxiarchs, otherwise known as Agioi Asomatoi sta Skalia (Saints Bodiless on the stairs, because it was initially dedicated to St. Bodiless Michael), was attached to the exterior west wall of Hadrian's Library, just next to the latter's entrance. It was a cross-shaepd inscribed church with an eight-sided dome, built in the 11th century. The inscriptions carved on the columns of the Library attest to the fact that this church belonged to the prominent Chalkokondyles' family. The church is well-attested in depictions made by foreign travelers of the 18th-19th centuries. At present there remain only some traces of the wall paintings, as the church was demolished in ca. 1842 for the sake of archaeological investigations, which aimed at revealing the ancient past of Greece.

On  the eastern corner of the Roman Agora, close to the Clocktower of Kyrrhestos, is preserved the facade of a building bearing arched openings crowined by lintels made of Hymettus' marble. On a piece of the inscription of the epistyle is preserved a dedication to Athena Archegetis and to Theoi Sebastoi, without any further information The identification of the building is made difficult by the fact that part of it is still buried under Marc Aurelius' street. The initial identification of the building as an 'agoranomeio', i.e. building which sheltered the controlleers of the agora, has been refuted and replaced by a proposal to identify the buildings as a 'Sebasteion', i.e. temple in honour of the Theoi Sebastoi (reverend gods), possibly Claudius and his wife as deified imperial couple. Thsi identification seems more plausible and the dating, in the mid-1st century AD., definitely fits.

In the early Christian period the clocktower of Cyrrhestus (i.e. Andronikos of Cyrrhus) was transformed into a baptistery attached to a nearby basilica. In the 15th century the monument is mentioned by the traveler Cyriacus of Ancona as a temple of Aeolus, apparently due to the representations of the personified winds. In the 18th century it was transformed into a 'tekke' (gathering house) of the Dervishes of the Mevlevi Order. It was therefore called 'Braimis' tekke' or Eflatun Cadiri (i.e. Plato's tent), due to its mention in Evliya Celebi's Seyahatname.

Athena Promachos  was a huge bronze statue, created by Pheidias around 470 B.C, The metal used for its construction came from the Persian booty at the battle of Marathon. Pausanias (Attica 28.2) mentions that the plume of the statue's helmet was visible to the ships arriving at Cape Sounion.

Aiakos was son of Zeus and the nymph Aegina, progenitor of the Aeakids and first king of the Myrmidons. He was considered the most righteous king on earth and therefore he was assigned the keys of the Underworld. His name was related to the minting of the first silver coin. Perhaps it was for these reasons that the Athenians had dedicated to a hero from Aegina a sanctuary. In the 4th century BC. the area was used as a granary.

The hill of Ares or of 'Arae'  (curses) or Areios Pagos is located northwest of the Acropolis It is an abrupt, sharp-pented limestone hill, 115 meters high; one can access its peak only by carved staris on the rock. In the archaeic period it functioned as the seat of an aristocratic council. After the reforms by Kleisthenes the body of Areios Pagos maintained only its character as a court, specialized in murder cases. It is here that takes place the climax of the tragedy 'Oresteia', when Orestes is exonerated. On its north footihill there is a small cave dedicated to the Erinyae, ie. the goddesses which tormented the murderers. From there came the etymology which connects the hill with the 'Arae', i.e. the curses. \nOn the hilltop is preserved a cubic rock, related with either the altar of Areia Athena or one of the two banks of the court house, the Hybris, where the accused stood, or the Anaedia (Insolence), where the accuser stood. \nAreios Pagos has become widely known due to the fact that here preached Apostle Paul when he visited Athens. His preaching won him at least one proselyte, namely St. Dionysius Areopagites, to whom is dedicated a little church on the north side of the hill.

The trail pasing from the cavea of the theatre going westwards leads to the sanctuary of Asclepius, located between the Peripatos and the rock of the Acropolis. The cult of Asclepius was introduced to Athens in 419 B.C. by a certain Telemachus from Epidaurus. The choice of the spot for its construction was due to the existence of a source in a cave of the rock, since running water was necessary for the cult of Asclepius. From the Peripatos one approaches the sanctuary through a propylon of the 1st century BC. which is located a bit to the left in comparison to the present-day entrance. \nThe monumental form of the sanctuary was adopted mainly in the 4th century B.C. from the little Doric prostyle, tetrastyle temple is preserved only the foundation.To the east of the temple there was a large altar and to the north , just under the cliff, there was a two-storeyed Doric portico, consisting of seventeen columns and containing a secon,d Ionic colonnade in its interior.This was the 'encoemeterion', i.e. the space where patients would sleep at night waiting for the god to appear in their dream and divulge the indicated therapy to them, as described by Aristophanes in his comedy 'Ploutos'.. At the west part of the portico there is a square pit dedicated to the cult of deities of the underworld. To the west there was once more portico, with Ionic columns this time, dated to the end of the 5th century. At its back side there were four rooms, which must have been used either as encoemetira as well or as banquet rooms for the pilgrims. Yet one more portico was added to the sourth of the main temple in the Roman period.. The sanctuary was destroyed in 267 AD but it was rebuilt in the 4th century, apparently by the emperor Julian. In the 6th century it was transformed into a three-aisled basilical church dedicated to Agioi Anargyroi (the healing saints). In the spring's cave which constituted the churche's baptistery there is the chapel of Zoodochos Pigi. To the west of the Asclepieion complex there was one more fountain, dedicated to Pan and the Nymphs since the archaic period. Furthermore, one can still discern two medieval cisterns and the foundations of two temples dedicated to Isis and Themis, dating from Hadrian's period.

The so-called Arrephorion is a square building, ereceted in the mid-5th century B.C. It comprised a vestibule and a hall. To the west of the building there was an open court, from which a secret passage led through the wall to the north slope of the Acropolis hill \nThe Arrephoria were celebrated in the month Skirophorion (i.e. between mid-June and mid-July) in honour of the goddess Athena. It comprised mystery rituals related to fertility and fruit-bearing of the earth. Arrephoroi, whose name derived from the expression 'arreta ferein' (i.e. bearing the unspeakable); they were virgins aged 7-20 years old, coming from prominent Athenian families. They stayed for a while on the Acropolis, in the Arrephorion, and helped with the weaving of the peplos of Athena Polias, offered to the goddess during the Panathinaia. However, their most important task was to participate at the mystery ritual of the Arrephoreia, during which they transported sacred objects through the secret passage to the north slope of the Acropolis. There, a member of the priesthood took them and handed over to the Arrephoroi other sacred objects to be transported to the Acropolis again. It has been suggested that these objects were little breads in the shape of snakes and phallic symbols, branches of pine tree and fruit.

The Basileios Stoa on the west end of the agora was a small portico (measuring 18 by 7,5 meters). It was the seat of the archon basileus and was built in ca 500 B.C. It is said that here were put up Solon's laws, carved on wooden stelae, called 'Kyrveis'. The stoa eight Doric columns on the facade and four in the interior. Clay acroteria with mythological themes decorated the building's roof. In the 4th century BC little wings were added to the north and south ends of the stoa, which nowadays is located outside of the fenced archaeological site of the Agora and its remains are visible between Adrianou street and the rails of the suburban railway.

Basilicas were Roman public buildings, where took place conventions and meetings or commercial activities. It was in basilicas, for example, that regional courts, the so-called assizes, where the provincial governors presided, took place. The Agora basilica, a building dating to Hadrian's time, functione more or less in this way. After the Christianization of the Empire, the basilica as an architectural type was used by Christians for their churches,

The Vespasians of the Roman Agora were public latrines. They are a rectangular, roofed building with a vestibule and a square hall with banks on all four sides, provided with holes, from where sewage pipes passed.

As one walks up Areos street from Monastiraki square, right on the junction with Adrianou street and next to Tzisdaraki's mosque, is located the facade of the library which the emperor Hadrian gave to the city of Athens in 132 AD. In the second century AD, according to Pausanias, the library was the most glamorous building of Athens. It has a rectangular plan, measuring 12x82 meters and is situated to the north of the Roman Agora. The central space of teh building is occupied by a peristyle courtyard measuring roughly 82x60 meters. The columns of the peristyle were made of Phrygian marble, dark with white and red veins Within the central courtyard there was initially an artificial lake and a garden, where the readers would go to think or relax. Nowadays one can see at the same spot the traces of a tetraconch building, dating to the early Christian church of Athens (first half of the 5th century AD). On the north and south side there were reading rooms consisting of a rectangular and two semicircular niches with banks. The main Library hall was located behing the eastern colonnade and consisted of a large hall with niches and wooden shelves, where the books were kept and two smaller rooms on both sides, probably serving also as reading rooms. These amll rooms communicated with larger ones, identified as lecture rooms, due to the discovery of a tribune in one of them. \nThe interior walls behind the perisyles were dcorated with marble slabs. The entrance to the building was from the western side through a propylon decorated with four fluted Corinthian columns made of Phrygian marble on a stepping stone of white pentelic marble. Plain Corinthian columns made of greenish Karystos' marble, seven on each side to the right and left of the propylon, decorate the facade. \nThe library was destroyed in 267, during the Erulian raids. Then, most of its coins were transported elsewhere, to decorate other buildings In 412 the governor Herculios repaired the building and slightly late the aforementioned tetraconch was constructed.

In ca 100 AD Titus Flavius Pantaenus built a library in honour of the goddess Athena, the emperor Trajan and the Municipality of Athens. The building, located to the south of the Stoa of Attalos, comprised a rectangular colonnaded courtyard, around which were situated several rooms. The main library hall to the east was a large, square room with a surface of about 100 sq.m. bearing a colonnade on the facade and a marble revetment in the interior. The surrounding walls were covered with bookcases. The rooms of the west and north sides were probably used as shops or workshops for sculptures. At present, the library's site is covered by the Late Roman wall. Its location was identified through the discovery of an inscription relating its regulations, now exhibited in the Agora Museum.

On the central square of the Agora one can see the Altar of the Twelve Gods. It consisted of a square enclosure, surrounded by low entablature. At present only one corner of it is visible, as the rest of the monument is covered by the rails of the railway. The altar was famous in antiquity, as a sacred space where people could find refuge. It was built in 522/1 BC, when archon was Peisistratos the Younger. and it constituted the starting point for counting distances, as it was considered the centre of the city of Athens.

To the east of the foundation of the Hekatompedos temple of Athens and to the northeast of the Parthenon, some carvings on the natural rock show that probably this was the location of the altar of Athena Polias. The archaic altar was destroyed in the course of the Persian invasion (400 BC) but it was probably built anew in the period of Pericles following the initial architectural form.

Dipylon was the most important gate of Athens. It was situated very close to the Sacred Gate, from where passed the procession of the Eleusinia. Its extent reached 1800 sq.meters. This means that it was one of the largest gates of the ancient world. Its older building phase dates to the years of Themistokles in 478 BC. It was protected by a strong wall and large corner towers. Part of the southwest tower has been preserved. \nUntil the end of the 4th century BC the gate was known as 'Thriasiai Pylai'because the broad street passing through it led to the Deme of Thria close to Eleusis, after crossing the suburb of Hekademos, the Academy. From that gate started the procession of the Panathinaia to the interior of the city, following the Panathenaic Way. In ca 307/306 BC the old gate was destroyed, probably due to an earthquake and a flood. Demetrius I Poliorcete built a new gate, called Dipylon due to the two gates located one next to the other. Behind the wall dividing the two there was a cylindrical altar dedicated to Zeus Erkeios, Hermes and the local hero Akamas. The gate probably collapsed after the destruction of Athens by the Erulians in 267 BC.

On the north end of the Acropolis hill is located the Erechtheion, i.e the house of the mythical king Erechteus. It was a building of the Ionian style, made of Pentelic marble. It is one of the most renowned monuments of Classical Antiquity, mainly because of its sculpted architectural decoration, particularly the Karyatids. \nIt was constructed between 421 and 405 BC in order to shelter the ancient cult relics related to the foundation myths of Athens, such as the scars on the rock made by Poseidon's trident, the olive tree of Athena, the ruins of the so-called mythical palace of Erechtheus, the tomb of Cecrops and cultic remains of the hero Voutes and of Pandrossos. \nIt was been suggested that it was designed by the architect Mnesikles. The building in the interior was divided by a rectangular wall in two parts, separated and independent. The facade of the east part formed a prostasis of six Ionian columns. In this part was kept the wooden idol of Athena Polias, which was vested with the sacred veil during the Panathenaia. In the western part were worshipped the other gods and heroes. On the north side, an elaborate prostasis with Ionian colonnade led to the interior, whereas a small door led to the sanctuary of Pandrossos, daughter of the Mythical king Kekrops. On the southwest end of the Erctheion one can still see the prostasis of the famous Caryatids, six female statues supporting graciously the marble roof instead of plain columns. The building was surrounded by a frieze made of dark-colourd eleusinian marble slabs bearing decoration in relief made of whit Pentelic marble and depicting local mtyhs. Part of the frieze are now exhibited in the Acropolis Museum.

In the course of the centuries the Erechtheion underwent several changes in its use. It was transformed into a church in the 6th century, into a palace in the 17th century by the Catalan conquerors of Athens and it also sheltered the harem of the Ottoman governor in the 15th century. \nIn the beginning of the 19th century, Lord Elgin rovved the sculptures of the monuments of the Acropolis, the Erechtheion nonetheless. Thus the building lost one of its six Caryatids, which is at present still situated in the British Museum. \nIn the course of the Greek Independence War it suffered serious damages (1827) and it took large-extent restoration work in order to give it back, as much as possible, its initial form.

After the Christianisation of the Roman Empire, the Acropolis ceased to be the centre of the 'pagan' cults, however the Parthenon was transformed into a Byzantine church, dedicated to Panagia Atheniotissa (Our Lady of Athens). High up on the columns were carved crosses and to the building were added an apse and naves. \nIn the Frankish period, the Parthenon remained a church, but as the Cathedral of the Latins. Finally, after the Ottoman conquest, Mehmed the Conqueror, an admirer of the ancient Greek civilization, ordered that the temple should not be destroyed, but to be transformed into a mosque. The Acropolis hill became the centre of the military command of the city, whereas in the free spaces among the ruins were built houses and auxiliary military buildings.

Heridanus is a tributary of Ilissos; it was named after the mythical son of Oceanus. Nowadays, the greatest part of its course is subterranean, lost under the concrete and the buildings of Athens. In Antiquity it flowed parallel to the Sacred Way. However, since it overflowed and caused the formation of swamps, particularly in the region of Kerameikos, but also because the waste of Athens ended up in it, it turned into a polluted river. Thus, the emperor Hadrian ordered that its course should be built-in and that the river should be covered with tiles. At present one can see part of its banks in the metro station of Monastiraki, whereas a part of the river, about two meters broad, flows freely in the Kerameikos cemetery.

The theatre of Dionysus, situates to the north of the god's sanctuary, is the most ancient and important Classical theatre in the world. Here were first performed the masterpieces of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides and Aristophanes. \nIt was carved on the natural slopes of the ground in the beginning of the 3th century, initially following a Π-shape. Only very few remains are still extant from this phase. The theatre took its present shape in 340-330 BC, under the auspices of the orator Lycurgus. The cavea was reveted with stone benches, the orchestra became round, there was constructed a sewage pipe on the circumference and the proscenium and the quintes were constructed. The cavea is divided in three parts by two corridors, of which the higher one was the continuation of the Peripatos, i.e. the pathway around the Acropolis hill, most familiar to the Athenians. The capacity of the theatre was about 17000 spectators. From the 2nd century BC the first row of seats were gradually replaced by tall marble thrones destined for the Athenian priesthood. These thrones are preserved in excellent condition and bear inscriptions. The central throne belonged to the priet of Dionysus. \nThe first excavations started by the Archaeological Society in 1841, they were continued by the German Archaeological Institute (1882-1895) whereas some digs took place throughout the 1960s and 1980s by the Greek Archaeological Service. An extended programme of restoration has brought the monument to a state much similar to its initial form.

The theatre of Dionysus suffered several transformations in the course of the centuries. During the Hellenistic period the scene, initially made of wood, became a two-storeyd marble construction. In the 1st century AD the proscenium was extended taking space from the orchestra which, thus, took the shape of a horseshoe; It became a three-storeyed construction and was decorated with representations in relief. To that period dates a marble epistyle with a dedicatory inscription to Dionysus and to the emperor Nero. The orchestra was paved and in the 3td century there was placed the marble rhomboid decoration, extant until today. In the same period, under the archon Phaedrus, there was created a tribune, the so-called 'tribune of Phaedrus', decorated with scenes in relief, inspired by the Dionysiac myth with the addition of colossal forms of kneeling satyrs. In the 3rd of 4th century a row of marble slabs were placed perpendicular all around the orchestra, thus turning the latter into an arena for dual battles.

To the south of Metroon there was a large circular building with an exterior diameter 18,33 meters. This was the tholos, which was built in ca 470-460 BC and constituted the building where the prytanes stayed and had their meals. At the same time the kyes of the temples and the official measuring units of the city were kept here. The excavations underneath the Tholos have revealed buildings of the Archaic period, from which one has been interpreted as the House of the Peisistratids. \nIn the interior, where one could enter from a gate to the east, six Ionian columns supported an Ionian roof, whereas in the centre there was an altar. In the Roman period the floor was covered with slabs, whereas an Ionain propylon was added at the entrance.

On the southeast end of the Acropolis hill, where the old Acropolis Museum stands, there are the remains of a sanctuary, which, according to the most prominent interpretation, was dedicated to the mythical king Pandion (son of Erichthonius of Cecrops). The building belonged to the building programme of Pericles and it dated to ca 440 BC. it consisted of a large open-air space with a propylon. Behind the sanctuary there was a smaller space, probably the workshop of the sculptors who worked on the building programme of the Acropolis.

On the southwestern corner of the Acropolis, to the east of the temple of Athena Nike and to the west of the Chalkotheke there are still extant the remains of the north and western wall of the sanctuary of Brauronia Artemis The building looked like a portico with two aisles and it probably dates to the 430s BC. In one of the aisles was kept the wooden idol of the goddess, probably seated, as well as a marble statue of her, made by the famous sculptor Praxiteles.

The sanctuary of Aphrodite Urania, related by Pausanias, who had seen within it the cultic statue of the goddess, work made by Pheidias, had been searched for in the past on the foothill of the north side of Kolonos Agoraios. According to a more recent view, the location of the sanctuary must have been to the west of the Poikile Stoa, where the remains of an elaborate marble altar of Aphrodite have been discovered, dating from the archaic period (ca 500 BC); the base of the altar (measuring 5.10x2.40 m) is discerned within the space of the excavations on the north side of Hadrianou Street.

The first monument visitors meet when entering the archaeological site of the South Slope of the Acropolis is the sanctuary of Dionysus. The precinct is not preserved entirely. Scattered around the sanctuary area are found the bases of altars and dedications, whereas the cylindrical alters of the Hellenistic and Roman periods are also preserved, decorated with garlands and theatrical satyrs' masks. \nThe north part of the precinct is bound by a Doric portico. 63 meters' long, dated to the 4th century BC Against its north wall leaned the scene of the theatre of Dionysus. In front of the west end of the portice is preserved the foundation of the Archaic temple, which sheltererd the wooden statue of the god Dionysus, transfered from the Boeotian city of Eleutherae (on the slopes of Mt. Cithaeron) at the time of Peisistratos (546-528 BC). The temple was of small dimensions (13.5 by 8 meters) distyle in antis made of local porous stone. Some recent discoveries of architectural culpture comprising a torso of a satyr and one of a warrior, are considered to belong to the pediments of the temple and date to the beginning of the 5th century BC. The more recent temple, the foundation of which can be discerened a few meters farther to the south, did not replace the Archaic one, but the two temples coexisted for several centuries, at least until the 2nd century AD, according to Pausanias. This temple was larger, Doric with a vestibule; it sheltered the gold and ivory statue of Dionysus, work by Alcamenes, a student of Pheidias. The archaeologist date this temple to the end of the 5th or the middle of the 4th century B.C.

The cemetery of Kerameikos is located to the northwest of the Ancient Agora, along Ermou street, close to its junction with Peiraeos street. It was the most important cemetery of the city. The river Eridanus flows through the area. To the east have been discovered the remains of the fortifications of Athens with the two main gates of the city -the Sacred Gate and the Dipylon- as wll as public buildings within the walls, such as the Pompeion and the Fountain. To the west spreads the ancient cemetery, where impressive burial monuments of private citizens as well as collective tombs of war victims are located. 
The findings of the long excavations carried out mainly by the German Archaeological School attest to the fact that Kerameikos spread from the northwestern slopes of the Acropolis down to the forest of the hero Academus, at a distance of about 1.5 klms. 
Thucydides relates that before the construction of the Themistoclean wall, in 478 BC, the entire Kerameikos was lcoated outside of the city wall. 
Kerameikos was a burial place already since the 12th century BC., mainly for the inhabitants of the surrounding communities. From the end of the 6th century BC onwards, the inhabitants of Athens ceased to bury their dead within the city boundaries and Kerameikos developed into the city's cemetery par excellence, in use until 86 B.C., Later on the region was abandoned and gradually it was buried by the material brought down by Eridanus. In 1871 the excavations began under the auspices of the Archaeological Society of Athens, whereas in 1913 the responsibility for the excavations was assumed by the German Archaeological Institute.

On the corner formed by the east wall of the Dipylon and its east tower are located the remains of a fountain, which was contemporary to the Dipylon and provided water to the city and the travelers. The fountain's cistern is forming a Γ-shape with a little portico consisting of three Ionian columns on its facade.

The builting of the Medrese (or Madrasa), i.e. of the Ottoman religious school of Athens, was located on present-day Diogenous street, opposite to the clocktower of Cyrrhestus According to the marble inscription on its main gate, still extant, it was built in 1721 by Mehmed Fahri. \nThe medrese of Athens was square in shape with an internal courtyards, around which spread eleven cells with a peristyle; here, the religious teachers gave their lectures, teaching courses such as reading, memorizing and interpreting the Qur'an, religious justice, theology, philosophy and Arabic, Persian and Turkish literature. Within the first year after the liberation of Greece, the Medrese was transformed into a prison with a large plane tree in the courtyards. Those who were destined for execution said the phrase 'Farewell to the plane tree', which has become proverbial until today, meaning 'this is never going to happen'. Later on, a second storey was added to the initial building. In 1914 started its gradual demolition but, due to the archaeological finds of the spot, ithe gate with its marble inscription as well as some minor parts of teh biuilding were preserved.

In the beginning of the 2nd century BC the ancient Agora was already renowned for its public buildings. The MIddle Stoa (Portico) was named so in order to be discerned from the rest of the porticoes. It was a huge, possibly commercial portico measuring 147 by 175 meters. It was built in ca 180 BC and divided the Agora in two parts. It had Doric colonnades on all sides. A perpendicular, probably Ionian, colonnade divided the building in two parts and on the lower

The remians of Agrippas' Odeion are located directly behing the stone Giants dominating till now thw centre of the Agora square. It was donated by Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa and was built in ca 15 B.C. along the north facade of the Middle Stoa. It was meant to be used as a place for concerts and musical events. Its main hall was a large area about 25 meters wide with a capacity of 1,000 spectators. The orchestra was semicircular, paved with opus sectile. The proscenium's facade was low and decorated with sculptures. On all three sides of the building (east, west, north) spread a two-storeyed portico. The walls on the outside were decorated with tall Corinthian columns and pillars. In the interior there were no supporting props, which ended up in the collapse of the roof in the 2nd century. The odeion was restored in ca 170 AD, but converted into a lecture hall for philosophers. The six colossal figures of Giants with serpents' tails and Tritons with fish tails were added at that point. Nowadays only three of these figures are preserved. The main hall's capacity was diminished, for better static results, and a perpendicular wall was added for the same reason. Agrippas' Odeion was destroyed by a fire in 267, during the Erulian invasion, and large part of its building material was transported and re-used in the Valerianian Wall of Athens. In the period after 400 AD a gymnasium was built here, which was later transformed in order to house the city's governor until the first half of the 6th century, when it was finally abandoned.

In ca 447 BC Pericles ordered the construction of an Odeion to the east of the theatre of Dionysus. Its construction was accomplished in 443 B.C. and it hosted the musical contests of the Panathenaia. Pausanias relates that its shape was imitating the tent of the Persian king Xerxes. It was rectangula, measuring 62,40x68,60 meters, bearing benches on the inside and a wooden roof supported by nine rows of columns. It was used for concerts, musical contests but also as a court.. It was completely destroyed in 86 BC by Sulla and was rebuilt in 61 BC, apparently on the same pattern, but entirely out of marble, which was paid for by Ariobarzanes II, king of Cappadocia. It was probably destroyed in 267 AD, during the Eruliian invasion.

Close to the southeast end of the Portico of Eumenes are situated the remains of one of the largest choregic monuments of Athens; it has the shape of a hexastyle prostyle Doric temple, built in ca 320/ 319 B.C. by Nicias. In the 3rd century BC the upper part of the monuments was almost entirely, into the Beulé gate of the Acropolis.

To the west of the Parthenon, almost touching on the east side of the sanctuary of ARtemis of Brauron, there are marks of limestone foundations and walls carved on the wall. These belon to a large rectangular room with three entrances on the north, long side and six columns in the interior. The building is identified through inscriptions as the Chalkotheke, built in ca the mid-5th century BC, in order to house the bronze votive offerings to the goddess Athens In the beginning of the 4th century to the north side was added a portico with nineteen columns, the notheast end of which is nowadays discernible on the carved stairs of the Parthenon. During the Roman period the building underwent serious transformation.

Fethiye (or Fetihie) Camii, i.e. the mosque of the Victory is located on the corner of the streets Panos and Pelopida, within the enclosure of the Roman Agora. Its name was due to the fact that when Mehmed the Conqueror arrived in Athens, in ca 1458, the basilica which was located in its position was transformed into a mosque. The present-day building was apparently built later, in ca 1669. The mosque is also known as 'Mosque of the (Grain) Market', due to its location close to the grain market in the course of the Ottoman period. Despite its historic value, it is not particularly important from the point of view of archtiectural originality. \nBetween 1687 (when Athens was conquered by the Venetian army of Francesco Morosini), until April 1688, the mosque was transformed into a Catholic church dedicated to st Dionysius of Arepoagus. After the departure of the Venetians it became a mosque again until the Greek Revolution. In 1824 it was used as a peer-to-peer school by the Philomuse Society, whereas it was later on managed by the Greek Army. In 1843 it was used as a guarding post. Around that time its minaret was demolished as part of the 'clearing' process from the Ottoman reminders. Later on it was used as a military jail, headquarters of the guard and military bakery.

Metroon was called the sanctuary of the Mother of God or Rhea. Such a sanctuary had been built within the Old Bouleuterion in the beginning of the Classical period, which was, however, destroyed during the Persian Wars In the second half of the 2nd century BC, the Metroon was reconstructed, probably at the expenses of Attalus II of Pergamon The architectural complex of the Hellenistic Metroon (measuring in total 38.83x29.56 meters) consists of four rooms, in front of which was ereceted a colonnade of 14 Ionian columns. The north room was larger, provided with an open peristyle court with a centrally positioined altar The second room from the south looked like a distyle temple in antis. Here were kept the catalogues of the male citizens, like what happens today with military conscription catalogues.

On the west side of the Agora, east of the Metroon, there was the Monument of the Eponymous Heroes, made in ca 330 BC. Presently, only the oblong pedestal is preserved, on which stood the bronze statues of the 10 eponymous heroes of the Athenian phylae (tribes), flanked by two bronze tripods. According to Pausanias, the heroes of the ten tribes were: Hippothoon, Antiochos, Aeas, Leos, Erechtheus, Aigeus, Oineus, Akamas, Cecrops and Pnadion. \nThe Monument was surrounded by a wooden fence supported by stone props. Its facade was used for hanging important public announcements. In the Hellenistic and Roman periods new tribes were added to honour non-Athenian kings, benefactors of Athens; hence the monument was modified to accommodate these changes. Thus, in 3097/6 BC two new statues in honour of Demetrius Poliorcete and his father, Antigonus, were added, whereas in 223 BC a third statue was added to honour Ptolemy Euergetes of Egypt. In 200 BC the statues of the Antigonids were removed and another one, honouring king Attalus I of Pergamon was added. In the 2nd century AD, the statue of the Roman emperor Hadrian was also added to the Monument.

In the Museum of the Ancient Agora, within the restored Stoa of Attalos,therre are displayed finds from the Ancient Agora archaeological site, revealing aspects of the daily life of ancient Athens. Among them there are a 5th century sand-clock for estimating time in the courts, pottery sherds used for the ostracism of renowned politicians of the 5th century, as well as bronze ballots of the 4th century BC courts. A particularly interesting exhibit is a marble ballot used by the Assembly in the 3rd-2nd century, when the Athenians were divided in 12 tribes. Among the inscriptions estant, one notices the law against tyranny (337/6 BC) issued under the archon Phrynichos. Important is also a bronze inscrived shield, part of the Athenian booty snatches from the Spartns during the battle of Sphakteria (425 BC). 
In the Museum there are also finds shedding light on the commercial and economic activity of the city, such as coins from the archaic period to the foundation of the Greek state, or the official weighs and measures used for grain and other products. 
The excavations brought to light also grave goods from Geometric cemeteries which occupied the site , among which golden earrings dated to 850 Bc and clay shoes dated to ca 900 BC, as well as little clay animals from childrens' tombs of the late classical period. Particularly interesting are the cooking pots and pans, little hearths and toys, such as dice and knuckles, as well as notes on shards, left by the Athenians. 
Finally, the museum showcases host also red- and black-figured vessels, such as an aryballos in the shape of an athlete, who ties around his head the victor's girdle (ca 530 BC), a Gorgos cylik (ca 500 BC) and an Exekias crater with a Hermes' scene (ca 520 BC).

To the southwest of the Propylaia, on the bastion protecting the main entrance of the Acropolis, is built the temple of Athena or Apteros Nike, an Ionian tetrastyle temple made of marble. It stands out for its grace and elegance, probably due to the plan made by Kallikrates. The construction of the temple started in ca 426 BC and was accomplished in 421 BC. \nThe frieze around the monument depicts the gods' banquet on the east side and battles fro the history and mythology of Athens on all three other sides Parts of this frieze are exhibited in the British Museum. The pediments depict the gigantomachy on one side and an amazonomachy on the other. The centreal akroterion probably depicted Vellerophontes and the Chimaira. \nIN 1687 the Ottomans demolished the monument in order to use its building material for the fortification of the Propylaia. Its architectural members, however, were preserved, apart from those taken by Lord Elgin. The temple was restored for the first time in 1842 and then again in 1936 and 1941. Between 2001 and 2005 took place tha last restoration phase and the monument was placed in its correct position.

The marble Doric temple of Ares (Mars) was built in ca 430 BC on the pattern of the temple of Hephaestus. It was initially located in another part of Attica, probably in Acharnae. In ca 15 BC it was dismantled and transfered within the Agora, set up on new foundation. Its transportation, as well as that of the Southeast and Southwest temple was part of the peculiar building programme of the Augustan era, including the transportation to the Agora of several exquisite specimens of classical architecture, mainly in order to accommodate the ruler cult.

To the northeast of the Parthenon, right on the highest point of the Acropolis hill there are traces of the foundation of a sanctuary that has been identified with that of Zeus Polieus. The sanctuary comprised a small temple and was included in the programme of reconstruction of the region NE of the Parthenon, which took place in the 3rd wuarter of the 5th century BC. In this sanctuary took place the sacrifices in the course of the Dipolieia or Dipolia or Voufania celebration in honour of Zeus Polieus, a ritual in the month Skirophorion (i.e. in the end of June), related to the end of the grain harvest and the happy outcome of the sprouting. It is in this place that Pausanias must have seen two statues of Zeus, one dated to the archaic period and another one, more recent, made in ca 330 BC by the sculptor Leochares.

On the hilltop of Agoraios Kolonos dominating the west side of the Agora there was built a large Doric temple made of Pentelic marble between 449 and 415 B.C. The temple was peripteral hexastyle with 13 columns on the long sides, measuring 31.8 by 13.8 meters. The vestibule and the opisthodomos were distyle in antis. The architect of the Hephaestion was probably the same as the one of the Temple of Poseidon at Sounio, of Ares in the Agora and of Nemesis in Rhamnous. \nIt was initially thought that the temple was dedicated to Theseus, whos heroic deeds are depicted in relief on the north and west side of the building. Hence it was called Theseion. However, systematic excavation in combination with the written sources proved that in fact it was a temple dedicated to Hephaestus and Athena Ergane, who were protecting the bronzesmiths and potters, whose workshops spread in the area behind the temple. In the sanctum of the temple there was a pedestal with a sculpted decoration in relief, on which stood the bronze statues of the two gods, made by Alcamenes. To the west of the temple there was discovered a pit with the sherds of the clay moulds used for the construction of both statues. In the 5th century BC, the temple was transformed intona church dedicated to St. George, The church functioned until 1835, which preserved it from decay Within the first century of te life span of the Greek state it was used also as a museum.

To the north of present day Adrianou street one can discern the west end of Stoa Poikile, which was discovered during the excavations of 1981. It was built in ca 460 B.C. It is a large portico (12.5 by 36 meters), built in the Doric order on the exterior, with a row of Ionian columns inside. The name Poikile (=decorated) was due to its decoration with a series of wooden panels bearing paintings of the most renowned painters of the Classical period, such as Polygnotos, Mikon, Panaenos. The paintings depicted war triumphs, of a mythological or historical context. For example it depicted amazonomachy, the Fall of Troy, Battle of Marathon, victory of the Athenians in Oinoe etc. These paintings were preserved till the begining of the 5th century AD. War booty was also hanging from the walls. Stoa Poikile was not functioning as a commercial centre It was just a gathering place for the citizens and only in very few cases was it used for a solemn public purpose, such as a courthouse. Stoa Poikile lent its name also to one of the most important philosophical schools in antiquity, namely Stoic school, as its founder, namelyu Zeno from Kition in Cyprus, preferred to teach here in ca 300 B.C.

The New Bouleuterion was a large rectangular building (measuring 16 by 22 metres) oriented to the south of the Agora. It consisted of a large rectangular meeting hall with wooden banks. In the beginning of the 3rd century B.C. a prostasis consisting of Ionian columns was added along the south side of the building along with an Ionian propylon; its foundatoins are discerned today to the southeast of the Metroon.

The Acropolis hill was a naturally fortified location, which was additionally fortified already since the Mycenaean period. The Cyclopean Wall, visible to the southeasdt of the Propylaea, dates to ca 1240 B.C. On the northwest side was later added the wall called by Thucydides 'Pelargikon'. 
When the Persians took over Athens in 480 B.C.these fortifications were still in use. After the Persian Wars, the widespread fear of further attacks led to an additional fortification of the North Slope instigated by Themistocles (479/8 B.C.). The so-called Themistocleian Wall was made with architectural members from the monuments destroyed by the Persians. In 467 BC. Cimon supported made a new fortification to the south using ashlar masonry, which Pericles made even taller. During the Erulian invasion in 267 A.D. on the western side was built yet a new fortification, part of which is the Beulé gate. 
The main fortification was still the Acropolis or the Castle, as was called in the Byzantine period. In the Frankish period, after 1204, important alterations took place on the western part of the fortification: the wall became higher and acquired bastions. 
The Beulé gater, on the west part of the Acropolis, was sealed and another entrance, under the tower of Apteros Nike, was created. The Propylaea were incorporated within the fortification system, while the so-called Frankish tower was built, which was maintained until 1875, when it was demolished to allow excavations to take place.

Between the theatre of Dionysus and the Herodeion is discerned a portico donated by the king of Pergamon Eumenes II (197-158 B.C.) to the city of Athens. This portico is one of the most splendid works of Pergamene architecture and looks like the Stoa of Attalus in the Aora. It aimed at protecting the spectators of the theatre from the weather. It was 163 meters long and 17.65 meters wide. The facade of the ground floor bore 64 Doric columns and its central part was supported by an Ionian colonnade consisting of 32 columns. On the upper floor there was an Ionian colonnade consisting of half-columns on the facade and another one in the interior bearing Pergamene capitals. At present part of the portico is restored. The majority of the architectural members were built with Pergamene marble. Over the arches of teh portico was built the
